author: By Lauren Hirsch and Mike Isaac
title: Elon Musk threatens to end Twitter deal without information on fake accounts.
description: Mr. Musk’s lawyers said Twitter was “actively resisting” his requests.
content: In a crisp, six-paragraph letter to Twitter on Monday, lawyers for Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, made his displeasure known.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson survives no-confidence vote over lockdown parties, but is left reeling politically.
description: More than 40 percent of lawmakers in Mr. Johnson’s own Conservative Party voted to remove him, a sign that he may struggle to remain prime minister.
content: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson survived a tense vote of no confidence on Monday, fending off a mutiny that nevertheless leaves him reeling and presages a volatile period in British politics, as he fights to stay in power and lead a divided Conservative Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jingyu Lin, Michael Paulson, Jolie Ruben and Matt Stevens
title: The Many Faces of the 2022 Tony Nominees
description: As Broadway embarked on its road to recovery, these 45 theater artists helped pave the way.
content: The Broadway season that just ended, the first since the pandemic shutdown, will be remembered for many reasons — the persistence of Covid, the death of Stephen Sondheim, the dwindled tourism and the indispensable understudies. It was a season for renewed appreciation: of song and storytelling and shared experiences, of a beloved art form and a rebounding industry. And it was a season that featured an extraordinary volume of work by Black artists, catalyzed by the social unrest of 2020. The 2022 Tony Awards, which take place June 12, offer an opportunity to honor some of Broadway’s best work; in anticipation of that event, we photographed and interviewed many of the performers, and a few of the writers, directors and choreographers, nominated for awards. Below are portraits and edited excerpts from the interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Harry Styles Repeats at No. 1 With ‘Harry’s House’
description: The One Direction singer’s latest solo album is the first since Adele’s “30” to go back-to-back atop the Billboard chart after debuting there.
content: A big week of vinyl sales made “Harry’s House,” the latest solo album by the One Direction singer Harry Styles, the fastest-selling release of the year so far. A lack of new competition kept it at No. 1 for a second week running.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: The Tony Awards and ‘P-Valley’
description: The 75th Tony Awards air on CBS. And Katori Hall’s “P-Valley” is back on Starz.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, June 6 - 12. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Jesus Jiménez
title: Tropical Storm Alex Drifts Into the Atlantic After Flooding Florida
description: The storm brought rain and strong winds to Bermuda before becoming a post-tropical cyclone.
content: Tropical Storm Alex brought strong winds and rain to Bermuda before becoming a post-tropical cyclone on Monday, days after the weather system caused flooding across South Florida and killed at least three people in Cuba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Harry’s Table Is a Food Hall by Way of Cipriani
description: The collection of counters and areas include a pasta station, markets, caviar and more.
content: What might be the city’s most luxurious food hall opens Wednesday in the new Waterline Square cluster of apartment towers on the Upper West Side. Called Harry’s Table, it’s the first food market from the Cipriani family organization and connects to their newly opened Bellini Restaurant. There’s a linear progression done in pale turquoise and tile, consisting of a coffee bar; a gelato and sweets counter; a juice bar; a salad bar for assembled or custom mixtures; a pasta station selling fresh and dried pasta; the Gastronomia, for prepared food to take away; a fish market; a butcher area; a counter for panini; and a pizzeria. There are areas for cheeses, charcuterie and caviar, and shelves are stocked with some unusual imports from Italy, like canned confit yellow tomatoes. Seating is available for snacking on the spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: There Has to Be a Tipping Point on Guns, Right?
description: Or maybe not.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know we’ll talk about Joe Biden’s gun-control proposals, but I wanted to ask how Dan is feeling — about Covid and the Celtics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Here are the latest developments from the war in Ukraine.
description: Russia’s bid to capture the key eastern city of Sievierodonetsk is faltering against a fierce Ukrainian counteroffensive that has reclaimed significant sections of the city, where Moscow has concentrated its troops with the goal of fully seizing the province of Luhansk.
content: Russia’s bid to capture the key eastern city of Sievierodonetsk is faltering against a fierce Ukrainian counteroffensive that has reclaimed significant sections of the city, where Moscow has concentrated its troops with the goal of fully seizing the province of Luhansk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
title: Potent Weapons Reach Ukraine Faster Than the Know-How to Use Them
description: Soldiers desperate for advanced arms to match their Russian enemies have resorted to Google Translate to decipher the instructions for their sophisticated new tools.
content: KHERSON REGION, Ukraine — Since Russia invaded, NATO nations have upgraded Ukraine’s arsenal with increasingly sophisticated tools, with more promised, like the advanced multiple-launch rocket systems pledged by the United States and Britain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Golden State Rebounds With Game 2 Win Over Celtics in N.B.A. Finals
description: After collapsing in the fourth quarter of Game 1, Golden State turned an early lead in Game 2 into a big-time victory to even the series.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — It was exactly the kind of release the fans at the Chase Center had been seeking — some reason to jump up out of their seats in a delirious celebration of this team they couldn’t believe had lost Game 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: In South Texas, Jessica Cisneros calls for a recount in her primary runoff against Representative Henry Cuellar.
description: The Cisneros campaign said a Texas Democratic Party certification of the results found that Mr. Cuellar was up by 281 votes.
content: Jessica Cisneros, the progressive South Texas immigration lawyer, said on Monday that she would formally demand a recount in her razor-thin runoff against Representative Henry Cuellar, the nine-term incumbent and moderate Democrat she has been trying to unseat for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Could One County’s Success With ‘Red Flag’ Orders Be a Model?
description: Suffolk County authorities have acted more often than their counterparts elsewhere in New York to seize weapons from the home of someone who has made a threat.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the one county in New York State where judges have issued the most red flag gun orders. We’ll also get a review of a play about a City Council from a New York City Council member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Administrative note: If you’re interested in receiving puzzles, brain teasers, solving tips and more in your inbox every week, sign up for the new Gameplay newsletter. The first edition will be sent on Thursday, June 9, 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: U.S. moves to seize 2 planes believed to belong to Roman Abramovich.
description: In new court filings, the F.B.I. said it had traced the aircraft to the Russian oligarch despite the shell companies involved in their ownership.
content: Federal authorities intend to seize two aircraft believed to be owned by Roman Abramovich, saying the Russian oligarch violated strict U.S. export regulations linked to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to court filings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gautham Nagesh
title: He Helped Cure the ‘London Patient’ of H.I.V. Then He Turned to Covid.
description: Ravindra Gupta, who led the efforts that resulted in the second case of a patient being cured of H.I.V., was drawn into pandemic research.
content: Visionaries is a limited series that looks at figures who are trying to transform the way we live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: A Frozen-Treat Journey Around Los Angeles, in 10 Delicious Stops
description: Our critic’s favorite ice creams, paletas, sorbets, shave ices and other summer delights.
content: Every now and then, on a hot day in northeast Los Angeles, you might wish for something sweet and icy and refreshing, and at that exact moment, a raspado vendor will appear. The serendipity of it! Riding in a magnificent converted golf cart, honking the horn as if responding to a local emergency (which he is, in a sense), he carries ice, sorbets, bottles of chamoy sauce and syrups, fruit and a vast array of bagged, spicy snacks to customize your order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Liu
title: Beijing relaxes Covid measures as fears of another outbreak linger.
description: The Chinese capital relaxed pandemic rules at midnight on Monday, including a ban on dining in, after a partial lockdown that lasted more than a month.
content: Beijing residents eagerly indulged in a privilege that they had not enjoyed in weeks: dining inside a restaurant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Arizona Officers on Leave After Watching Man Struggle and Drown
description: “How far do you think he’s going to be able to swim?” an officer asked before Sean Bickings drowned in a lake in Tempe, Ariz., newly released footage shows.
content: Three Tempe, Ariz., police officers are on paid leave amid an investigation into their response to a man who jumped into a lake and, despite his repeated pleas for help, drowned as the officers watched, newly released video footage and records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: High California Gas Prices Rattle Democrats Ahead of Midterms
description: “I don’t hear anything about the other national issues we’re focusing on in Washington,” a congressman said. A driver put it succinctly: “I’m really unhappy.”
content: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Orange County, Calif., symbolized Republican struggles in America’s diverse and highly educated suburbs during Donald J. Trump’s presidency, as a backlash to Mr. Trump transformed center-right strongholds into increasingly Democratic territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: She Dreams of California While Stranded on a Cargo Ship in China
description: A crew has had to remain on its ship since February because of Covid-related delays in repairs and quarantine rules.
content: Sometimes Madeleine Wolczko dreams of her runs up the mountainsides of the Sierra Nevada, or the weekends diving for abalone off the Mendocino coast. Her only travels these days are in her mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Post-Roe America
description: We look at what abortion access would look like.
content: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, more than 20 states — home to roughly half the country’s population — are likely to outlaw nearly all abortions. For women living in Mississippi, the closest place to receive a legal abortion might then be Illinois.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Ukraine’s Training Problem
description: Ukrainian troops don’t know how to use many of the advanced weapons sent by the West.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: Biden v. Musk
description: The President’s comment on Friday dismissing the billionaire entrepreneur is the latest barb in Biden’s unfortunate feud.
content: Andrew here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: For Nikki Walton, Writing About Hair Was Just Step 1
description: At the height of her success as a leader of the natural hair movement for Black women, the author known as CurlyNikki started asking the big questions.
content: In 2013, Nikki Walton had a thriving website, a best-selling book and a schedule packed with promotional events and appearances on TV talk shows. And yet she felt something was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: A Conservative Quits Georgetown’s Law School Amid Free Speech Fight
description: Ilya Shapiro, who tweeted that a “lesser Black woman” would get a Supreme Court nod, was cleared by a school investigation. He decided to leave anyway.
content: On Thursday, Ilya Shapiro, a legal scholar, announced his victory in the campus free speech wars: After a suspension and an investigation over a series of tweets, he was cleared to take his new job as a senior lecturer and executive director at Georgetown University’s Center for the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Potential Dark Side of a White-Hot Labor Market
description: The strong job market may be about to take a turn for the worse. That could come to haunt those who made choices based on today’s conditions.
content: Shanna Jackson, the president of Nashville State Community College, is struggling with a dilemma that reads like good news: Her students are taking jobs from employers who are eager to hire, and paying them good wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: ‘How Am I Going to Feed Her?’ Parents of Premature Babies Struggle Amid Formula Shortage
description: Many newborns who spend time in the NICU rely on specialized formula to thrive. But their parents can’t find it anywhere.
content: Cameron Stripling’s twin girls were born in February, 13 weeks before their due date, weighing a little over one pound each. Though one of her babies is still in a neonatal intensive care unit in Anchorage, Alaska — six hours from her home — Ms. Stripling, 27, considers herself “really, really lucky.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Hurd
title: I’m a Republican Who Represented Uvalde in Congress. I Want More Than Thoughts and Prayers.
description: There are real solutions to this epidemic. We just need the courage to act.
content: Last month, a fourth-grade classroom in Uvalde, Texas, a small, quiet community that I represented in Congress, became a war zone. Nineteen beautiful, innocent children and two dedicated, brave teachers are gone forever because of a vicious massacre. It’s infuriating. It’s heartbreaking. It was preventable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court May Hear ‘800-Pound Gorilla’ of Election Law Cases
description: Next week the justices will consider whether to resolve a long-simmering dispute about the power of state legislatures in federal elections.
content: WASHINGTON — In October 2020, with the presidential election looming, four conservative justices issued opinions that seemed prepared to endorse a legal theory that would radically reshape how federal elections are conducted. The theory would give state legislatures independent power, not subject to review by state courts, to set election rules at odds with state constitutions, and to draw congressional maps warped by partisan gerrymandering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Axon Pauses Plans for Taser Drone as Ethics Board Members Resign
description: After Axon announced plans for a Taser-equipped drone that it said could prevent mass shootings, nine members of the company’s ethics board stepped down.
content: As nine members of its ethics board resigned, Axon, the company that developed the Taser, announced on Sunday that it was pausing plans to develop a stun-gun-equipped drone that it said could be used to prevent mass shootings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico President Will Not Attend Americas Summit in Blow to Biden
description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said he made the decision because Cuba, Nicaragua and Venezuela were not invited.
content: MEXICO CITY — In a rebuke to President Biden, the president of Mexico, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, said Monday that he would not attend the Summit of the Americas in Los Angeles after news emerged that the United States would not invite Cuban, Venezuelan and Nicaraguan leaders to the meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Boris Johnson Stays in Power
description: Britain’s prime minister survived a no-confidence vote.
content: Prime Minister Boris Johnson will continue to lead the Conservative Party — and, therefore, Britain — after a dramatic late-night decision on Monday threatened his grasp on power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, David Gelles and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden to Pause New Solar Tariffs as White House Aims to Encourage Adoption
description: Critics said the move would shortcut an investigation by the Commerce Department, which has been considering whether to impose the tariffs as part of a trade case against Chinese companies.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Monday announced a two-year pause on imposing any new tariffs on the solar industry, a decision that follows an outcry from importers who have complained the levies are threatening broader adoption of solar energy in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Democrats Weigh a Comeback Strategy in Factory Towns
description: The party can ill afford to continue bleeding working-class support in Midwestern states. A new report explores how “progressive populism” could offer a way forward.
content: Should Democrats bother competing in the struggling factory towns of the Midwest?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: This Optical Illusion Has a Revelation About Your Brain and Eyes
description: Your pupils may be dilating when you see images like this one as your brain tries to anticipate the near future.
content: Do not be alarmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Punctuality Is Having a Moment
description: “Fashionably late” falls out of fashion after more than two years of remote work, when, for many people, there was no good reason to be tardy.
content: The start time for the party to celebrate Tina Brown’s new book, “The Palace Papers,” was 6:30 p.m., and that’s when the media crowd began streaming into Michael’s, the bistro in Midtown Manhattan known for its power lunches. By 6:35, the place was packed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: A Broken Redistricting Process Winds Down, With No Repairs in Sight
description: A brutal battle over drawing district boundaries in the House of Representatives has left the two major political parties roughly at parity. But no one is celebrating.
content: WASHINGTON — The brutal once-a-decade process of drawing new boundaries for the nation’s 435 congressional districts is limping toward a close with the nation’s two major political parties roughly at parity. But the lessons drawn from how they got there offer little cheer for those worried about the direction of the weary American experiment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: In Britain, a New Test of an Old Dream: The 4-Day Workweek
description: A six-month program involving thousands of workers across 70 companies in Britain will be the latest effort to assess the effects of a shorter workweek.
content: LONDON — Thousands of employees across 70 companies in Britain started the first day of a four-day workweek on Monday, a pilot program that is the latest test in the decades-long quest to scale back workers’ hours while they earn the same amount of pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: The Mets Keep the Doors Open, the TV On and Opponents on Edge
description: Splitting a series with the high-spending Dodgers was a good start to the Mets’ West Coast trip. Dodging a few potential injuries was even better.
content: LOS ANGELES — The weekend didn’t quite go the way the Mets imagined it would to open their 11-day, 10-game tour of Southern California, but their rules of engagement became pretty clear: Leave the hotel doors open, the television on and make sure Pete Alonso keeps swinging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Big City Mayors, Furious About Mass Shootings, Fear Sweeping Gun Limits Are Out of Reach
description: Mayors described being caught in an exasperating partisan impasse, charged with managing the country’s carnage but pushed to the margins when trying to fix it.
content: RENO, Nev. — As the mayors filed into the conference room, they received a pamphlet called the “Mass Shooting Protocol” that included practical tips on coordinating with the police, setting up family reunification centers and organizing vigils. Make sure to post updates on a single social media account, the brochure advised. Immediately set up a fund for donations. Keep the news media away from victims’ loved ones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Jubilee, Britons Find Respite From Woes
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 6, 2022.
content: “I’m pretty sure the jubilee atmosphere is a four-day wonder, and that the national mood will turn fairly sour again fairly quickly. It feels like we’re all waiting for something to happen. For the storm or the dam to break.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Taylor
title: Building a Juneteenth Menu for the 21st Century, One Recipe at a Time
description: The cookbook author Nicole Taylor reflects on her journey to create a collection of Juneteenth recipes that revel in the breadth of the African American experience.
content: African Americans crave locally harvested, coast-to-coast, U.S.D.A. Prime liberty, in all its bitter sweetness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Violent Crime Is Up as Cities Lose Police Officers. What Now?
description: Some urban police departments are struggling to keep their numbers up.
content: For the second time in three years, the United States enters the summer amid a storm of anger at the police. The reports and videos suggesting a delayed and chaotic police response to the Uvalde shooting and the conflicting statements made by law enforcement leadership have rightfully bewildered and enraged millions of people across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Wells Fargo Announces ‘Pause’ of Policy That Led to Fake Job Interviews
description: The bank’s leaders will study how its “diverse slate” requirement is being carried out and what needs to change before restarting it in July.
content: Wells Fargo is temporarily suspending a hiring policy that led some managers to conduct sham interviews of nonwhite and female candidates, following a report by The New York Times highlighting the practice, the bank’s chief executive, Charles W. Scharf, told employees in a letter on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A candidate in Georgia who appeared to get few Election Day votes was actually in first place.
description: The discrepancy in a race for a county-level board of commissioners seat was blamed on a series of technical errors.
content: A candidate for a county office near Atlanta was vaulted into first place after a series of technical errors made it appear that she had not mustered a single Election Day vote in a vast majority of precincts in last month’s Democratic primary, election officials determined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A political escape artist finds his career on the brink.
description: When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”
content: When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: Students, We Want to Hear What You Have to Say About School Shootings
description: Opinion wants to know what you are thinking and feeling in the aftermath of school shootings.
content: How many words have adults spoken in the aftermath of mass shootings in America, and are we any safer? Countless words. Countless arguments about gun control and gun violence. Countless thoughts and prayers. Adults have been doing the talking since Buffalo, Uvalde and Tulsa; now it’s time for us to listen too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Eric Krupke, Sydney Harper, Carlos Prieto, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: What Depp v. Heard Means for #MeToo
description: The winning legal strategy could change the dynamics of the era.
content: This episode contains strong language and details of a sexual assault accusation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Fête du Pain for Hot Bread Kitchen’s Specialties
description: Bakeries around New York City that work with the incubator will offer special items throughout June.
content: This month, bakeries across the city are paying homage to Hot Bread Kitchen, a career training program and incubator that has supported immigrant women and people of color starting their own businesses since 2008. For what they’re calling the Fête du Pain, established bakeries that participate in the organization’s Quality Jobs Lab, an effort to create better jobs, are offering specialties for which Hot Bread Kitchen is known. (A portion of proceeds benefit Hot Bread.) In Manhattan, Russ & Daughters will have bialys and Amy’s Bread is featuring challah. The Brooklyn bakeries include Runner & Stone with M’smen Moroccan flatbread, Colson Patisserie offering Nan-e Qandi Persian bread and L’Imprimerie with baguettes. La Boulangerie de François in Queens will sell pecan currant bread. Dates for availability are listed on Hot Bread's website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: We Need to Stay Heartbroken About This
description: After the massacre in Texas, the children’s author Kate DiCamillo captured the depth of our grief.
content: NASHVILLE — I wish I could report that shock was my first reaction to the news from Uvalde, but it was not shock. My first reaction to the slaughter of 19 children and two teachers was grief — terrible, garment-rending grief — followed by something dangerously close to resignation. Here we go again. And again and again. When you know something unbearable will happen, and then it happens, grief and resignation sit together in the same pew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Denim Apron for Serious Grilling
description: Designed by the company BlueCut, it is made with flame-resistant denim and stitching with fire-retardant threads.
content: No nonsense protection is what this sturdy pitmaster apron delivers. It was designed by BlueCut with input from Daniel Castillo, whose Heritage Barbecue in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., draws crowds for his Texas-style fare. It’s also extra wide, made from flame-resistant denim with thicker quilting in the belly area to insulate from heat, stitched with fire-retardant threads, and sports a couple of pockets and a towel loop. There are jeans-style copper rivets and orange straps secured with leather, and it’s machine washable. Must we remind you of Father’s Day?
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: June 6, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 6, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel’s Government Teeters Again, Losing Vote on Law that Supports West Bank Settlers
description: The vote’s failure — from defections within the governing bloc and a power move by usually pro-settler opposition lawmakers — could topple the government and throw a lifeline to former Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
content: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Parliament voted on Monday against applying Israeli civilian law to Israelis in the occupied West Bank, a decision that edged the fragile coalition government closer to collapse and undermined the two-tier legal system that distinguishes between Israeli settlers and Palestinians in most of the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Brian X. Chen
title: Apple unveils new software to make the iPhone and other products feel new.
description: The company, for the first time since the pandemic started, invited technologists and press to a kickoff for its annual developer conference at its Silicon Valley campus.
content: CUPERTINO, Calif. — More than two years into the coronavirus pandemic, Apple made a big push on Monday to return to normalcy by inviting hundreds of software developers and journalists to its campus for an unveiling of a range of new software features that expand the iPhone’s utility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lorenzo Mittiga
title: Behold the Lionfish, as Transfixing as It Is Destructive
description: Lionfish, while spectacularly beautiful, are wreaking havoc on Caribbean reef habitats.
content: The silence underwater is overwhelming. Time passes quickly. Having spotted my target, I focus on it intensely, knowing that if I miss, and the animal gets away, it may learn from the encounter and be harder to hunt in the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: British pound and stocks rise as vote on prime minister washes over markets.
description: Markets are moved more by global concerns, like the war in Ukraine, than by domestic political infighting.
content: Financial markets appeared unperturbed by the political shock waves following the announcement that Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, would face a no-confidence vote in his leadership. When he won the vote, they continued as they had before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: An Attempt at Inclusion Proves There Is More Work to Do
description: A day after the Dodgers finally embraced the memory of Glenn Burke — Major League Baseball’s first gay player — a group of Rays players undercut their team’s Pride Night.
content: Something was missing in the top of the eighth inning on Saturday at Tropicana Field in St. Petersburg, Fla. The Tampa Bay Rays used two relief pitchers that inning — the left-handers Brooks Raley and Jalen Beeks — who wore jerseys without a patch on their right sleeve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Nadal Has a Chance at Winning All 4 Grand Slams, if His Foot Cooperates
description: Rafael Nadal said he planned to have his chronic left foot injury treated before Wimbledon begins in three weeks, then decide whether to play.
content: PARIS — Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer have won and done so much in nearly 20 years of hoarding the loot in men’s tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Battered by Russian Shells, a Monastery Remains Loyal to Moscow
description: The monks and nuns cloistered in a monastery complex in eastern Ukraine absorb daily bombardments from Russian artillery. And yet they remain loyal to the Russian Orthodox Church.
content: SVIATOHIRSK, Ukraine — Of the hundreds of battle sites all across Ukraine, the Sviatohirsk Monastery of the Caves surely ranks among the most incongruous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Guerrilla Attacks Signal Rising Resistance to Russian Occupation
description: Fueled by brutal Russian repression and worsening humanitarian conditions, Ukrainian partisans appear to be striking deep inside Russian-controlled territory.
content: The Kremlin-backed mayor of the Ukrainian town of Enerhodar  was standing on his mother’s porch when a powerful blast struck, leaving him critically wounded. A week later, about 75 miles away, a car packed with explosives rocked the office of another Russian-appointed official in the occupied southern city of Melitopol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Mercedes-Benz recalls nearly 1 million vehicles over brake issue.
description: The German carmaker said possible corrosion could cause the brakes in two of its S.U.V.s and in a luxury minivan model to malfunction.
content: Mercedes-Benz is recalling nearly one million cars that were sold around the globe between 2004 and 2015 over concerns that the brakes could fail, the company said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Phil Mickelson Will Play Rival Saudi-Backed Golf Tour’s Debut Event
description: “I fully realize and respect some may disagree with this decision,” said Mickelson, who hasn’t competed since his comments about the contentious tour were reported in February.
content: Phil Mickelson, who has not played competitively since incendiary remarks he made in support of a Saudi-backed golf league that hopes to rival the established PGA Tour were reported in February, will end his self-imposed layoff later this week by playing in the first event of the upstart LIV Golf circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: How Boris Johnson Shattered His Own Invincibility
description: The prime minister survived a no-confidence vote, but has been politically wounded by the same baffling mix of strengths and foibles that propelled his rise: rare political intuition, and breathtaking personal recklessness.
content: LONDON — When Boris Johnson won a landslide election victory for his Conservative Party in 2019, he loomed as a colossus over British politics, the man who had redrawn the country’s political map with a vow to “get Brexit done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Raising Raffi,’ a Father’s Lucid Book About a Chaotic Scene
description: In his new memoir, Keith Gessen wonders if his young son is more badly behaved than other children.
content: Diaper backward, Marshall McLuhan noticed, spells “repaid.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Assassinations Become Weapon of Choice for Guerrilla Groups in Myanmar
description: A movement to restore democracy has evolved into deadly warfare between a ruthless military and a resistance force with limited weaponry.
content: The gunman entered the small government office in central Myanmar, walked up to the man in charge and shot him four times in the head. “You are the ward administrator!” the gunman shouted, according to a brief video clip that captured part of the shooting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Britain’s prime minister, beset by a scandal over lockdown parties, faces a decisive vote.
description: Members of the British leader’s party reached a threshold to hold the vote, after he had come under fire about claims he misled Parliament about Downing Street parties during the pandemic.
content: Conservative lawmakers dealt Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain a potentially lethal blow to his leadership when they triggered a no-confidence vote on Monday that could force him from power a little more than two years after his landslide election victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Pete Buttigieg, the U.S. transportation secretary, tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: Mr. Buttigieg, who a White House spokesman said was not considered a close contact of President Biden, is at least the fifth cabinet secretary to test positive in about the last month.
content: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg said on Monday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus, the latest member of President Biden’s cabinet to be infected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Young Horn Player Could Become ‘a Real Legend’
description: At 21, Nathaniel Silberschlag landed a principal seat with the storied Cleveland Orchestra. Now tenured, he doesn’t ever want to leave.
content: When the Cleveland Orchestra brought Mahler’s Fifth Symphony to Carnegie Hall in 2019, its conductor, Franz Welser-Möst, lowered his baton and paused before the Scherzo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Erik Tanner
title: ‘You Don’t Become Lou Reed Overnight.’ A New Exhibition Proves It.
description: “Lou Reed: Caught Between the Twisted Stars” offers glimpses of a life in rock ’n’ roll — from doo-wop to “Metal Machine Music” — and tracks the evolution of one of music’s polarizing legends.
content: At a glance, it is a modest artifact: a five-inch reel of audio tape, housed in a plain cardboard box. Its wrapping bears a postmark of May 11, 1965, and the sender and addressee are the same: Lewis Reed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: With Cornyn in the Room, Senate Gun Talks Focus on Narrow Changes
description: The conservative Texan’s involvement in bipartisan talks means that an agreement, if there is one, is likely to include incremental steps.
content: WASHINGTON — Facing a national crisis with a devastating human toll and entrenched partisan divisions, a small group of Senate Republicans and Democrats pushed forward on high-stakes bipartisan talks that seemed unusually promising — right until the moment they collapsed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Green Drags the Warriors Back Into the Fight
description: A fiery star tests some limits in carrying Golden State over Boston in Game 2.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — There is a line. Draymond Green knows the line well at this stage of his career. Sometimes he uses his arms and elbows and vocal cords to push right up against the line. And there are other occasions when he enthusiastically tramples all over it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Gadget for Espresso on the Go
description: The Nanopresso Portable Espresso Maker uses a pumping system to release an inky 2.7-ounce shot.
content: This clever new gadget from the MoMA Design Store provides a well-made espresso at a moment’s notice. Hot water and coffee grounds are enclosed in separate compartments in its compact housing; they join forces through a hand-operated pressure pumping system to release an inky 2.7-ounce shot. A tiny cleaning brush and a measuring scoop fit into the assembly along with the cup, and it has a zippered, insulated carrying case. The overall length is seven inches, with the case, and it weighs less than a pound. It can also be ordered from the manufacturer Wacaco in Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: A group supporting Herschel Walker gave out gas vouchers. Georgia Democrats cried foul.
description: The group handed out $25 fuel vouchers and Walker campaign flyers to motorists in line at a downtown Atlanta gas station.
content: ATLANTA — A gas-money giveaway in support of Herschel Walker, the Republican candidate for Senate in Georgia, drew the ire of Democrats and voting rights groups in the state, who said the move was both hypocritical and possibly illegal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Paul Vance, Lyricist Behind an ‘Itsy Bitsy’ Bikini, Dies at 92
description: His daughter’s experience wearing a bikini on a beach in 1960 inspired him to write a novelty song that became a No. 1 hit.
content: Paul Vance, who described the uncertain path of a girl in a risqué two-piece bathing suit as she advanced from a locker to the shore in the novelty hit song “Itsy Bitsy Teenie Weenie Yellow Polka Dot Bikini,” died on May 30 in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Jones
title: A Couples Counselor Takes On ‘Normal Marital Hatred’
description: In his new book, ‘Us’, Terrence Real explores how ‘enlightened self interest’ could save your relationship.
content: As a family therapist for more than 25 years, Terrence Real sees how often couples fail to compromise or repair damage when things go awry. In his new book “Us: Getting Past You and Me to Build a More Loving Relationship,” he argues it is because we’ve created “a toxic culture of individualism.” We know relationships are hard work, says Mr. Real, who has counseled thousands of couples across the country, including Bruce Springsteen and his wife, Patti Scialfa. “But we don’t know how to deal with that. We don’t teach how to speak with love, how to negotiate, how to deal with grief.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Virtual Wine Session With Jancis Robinson
description: The English expert will hold an event for the 92nd Street Y, New York on the wines of California, Washington, Oregon and New York.
content: Jancis Robinson, the esteemed English wine expert, turns her laser palate to the wines of North America in an online session for Roundtable by the 92nd Street Y, New York. Though most of the talk will feature the wines of California, Washington and Oregon, she will also explore New York’s Finger Lakes and Long Island wineries. She will cover characteristics of the various regions and their wines, environmental concerns, and how to select and serve wines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Phuc Phan Thi
title: It’s Been 50 Years. I Am Not ‘Napalm Girl’ Anymore.
description: The surviving people in war photographs, especially the children, must somehow go on. We are not symbols. We are human.
content: I grew up in the small village of Trang Bang in South Vietnam. My mother said I laughed a lot as a young girl. We led a simple life with an abundance of food, since my family had a farm and my mom ran the best restaurant in town. I remember loving school and playing with my cousins and the other children in our village, jumping rope, running and chasing one another joyfully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson makes his case: ‘I will lead you to victory again.’
description: In a speech to his fellow Conservatives, the prime minister warned against “pointless fratricidal debate.”
content: In a speech to his fellow Conservative lawmakers, Prime Minister Boris Johnson argued that the best was yet to come if they continued to support him, and that he would prove an election winner for a second time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: The Summer Outlook
description: The latest U.S. Covid wave seems to be spreading west, even as it starts to recede in the Northeast.
content: As summer ramps up, the latest U.S. Covid wave seems to be spreading west, even as it starts to recede in the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Irma Vep’ Returns, More Meta Than Ever
description: In this new HBO series by Olivier Assayas, a continuation of his self-referential cult film from 1996, past and present are inextricably intertwined.
content: Most shows fall within recognizable categories: original stories, spinoffs, docudramas or, increasingly, reboots and revivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Elder
title: The (No Longer) Secret World of Surf Spots
description: Publicizing certain surf spots, especially ones off the beaten path, is similar to violating the first rule of Fight Club. Instagram and some new surfers have threatened that reverence.
content: As one of the world’s most productive wave hunters, Josh Mulcoy is used to keeping his discoveries to himself, whether it’s a remote beach or in his backyard of Vancouver Island, British Columbia. But nowadays, Mulcoy, a professional surfer and photographer, takes more care than ever about what information he shares — and what he doesn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Marshall
title: Democrats Can Win This Fall if They Make One Key Promise
description: To make the 2022 elections a referendum on Roe, Democrats have to put protecting Roe and abortion rights on the table.
content: Democrats hope to make November’s midterm elections a referendum on Roe v. Wade, the linchpin decision upholding abortion rights, which the Supreme Court is almost certain to strike down this summer. That strategy makes sense. Polls show that roughly two in three Americans oppose overturning Roe and almost 60 percent support passing a bill to set Roe’s protections in a federal law. What’s more, polls showed a rising number of voters listing abortion as their top midterm issue after news of Roe’s imminent demise leaked in the form of a draft court opinion published by Politico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Francis Mallmann Gives Vegetables Time in the Fire
description: The Argentine chef known for cooking over open flame has a new cookbook with vegetables and fruits suitable for grilling.
content: Long considered the meat maestro when it comes to grilling, the Argentine chef and restaurateur Francis Mallmann has turned his attention to plants. His latest, vibrantly-illustrated tome, written from his outpost in the Patagonia region, covers fruits and a dozen different vegetables suitable for grilling. Accommodating a standard Weber grill with other equipment, including a plancha and a Dutch oven, he takes the cook through charred fennel, scorched brussels sprout leaves, roasted cabbage, smashed potatoes and seared beets with their greens. He suggests grilling polenta and even a dense form of hummus. Only a wood or charcoal fire can coax proper results from some of the vegetables. There are a seven cocktail recipes, with grilled components. But a second volume will be necessary to address the mushrooms, chicories, alliums and peppers not covered here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Britain’s Jubilee celebrations.
content: At least five missiles hit Kyiv early yesterday, the first Russian strike in Ukraine’s capital in over a month. Russia said the missiles destroyed tanks and armored vehicles supplied by Ukraine’s Eastern European allies. At least one person was injured, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: From the Big Short to the Big Scam
description: Fraud aside, what are cryptocurrencies for?
content: Remember “The Big Short”? The 2010 book by Michael Lewis, made into a 2015 film, told the story of the 2008 global financial crisis by following a handful of investors who were willing to bet on the unthinkable — the proposition that the huge rise in housing prices in the years before the crisis was a bubble, and that many of the seemingly sophisticated financial instruments that helped inflate housing would eventually be revealed as worthless junk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Bamboo Is a Salve for Impoverished Nepal
description: The ubiquitous crop yields a degree of economic freedom — and lessons for other needy nations.
content: Bamboo makes a fascinating case study of how to do developmental assistance right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Ms. Marvel’ Introduces a New Hero (and a New Actress)
description: This Disney+ series, about a teenage Muslim superhero, represents the first screen role for its 19-year-old star, Iman Vellani.
content: When Iman Vellani watches herself as the title character in “Ms. Marvel,” she cannot help but feel a sense of disbelief. Before this Disney+ series came her way, she was a high school senior with a seemingly impossible dream to be in a Marvel project — now she’s playing one of its powerful costumed champions, just like some of the actors she has spent her life idolizing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
title: High-tech Western Weapons Pose Challenge for Untrained Ukrainian Soldiers
description: Ukrainian fighters are getting increasingly sophisticated weaponry from abroad. Some have been reduced to Googling instructions.
content: Staring through the sight attached to an anti-tank gun camouflaged in netting and green underbrush, Junior Sgt. Dmytro Pysanka is greeted with a kaleidoscope of numbers and lines that, if read correctly, should give him the calculations needed to fire at approaching Russian forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: British Tourist Gets 15 Years in Iraqi Jail for Taking Shards From Archaeology Site
description: The retired geologist said he did not know it was illegal to take the pottery shards when he picked them up from the site. The harshness of his sentence came as a surprise.
content: A British tourist who took pottery shards from an archaeological site was sentenced on Monday to 15 years in an Iraqi prison after a Baghdad court convicted him of trying to smuggle the artifacts out of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Adam Goldman and Luke Broadwater
title: Proud Boys Charged With Sedition in Capitol Attack
description: An amended federal indictment charged five members of the far-right group, including Enrique Tarrio, its former leader, with seditious conspiracy for their roles in the Jan. 6 assault.
content: Enrique Tarrio, the former chairman of the Proud Boys, and four other members of the far-right group were indicted on Monday for seditious conspiracy for their roles in the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6 of last year, some of the most serious criminal charges to be brought in the Justice Department’s sprawling investigation of the assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Thefts, Fraud and Lawsuits at the World’s Biggest NFT Marketplace
description: OpenSea, one of the highest-profile crypto start-ups, is facing a backlash over stolen and plagiarized nonfungible tokens.
content: Chris Chapman used to own one of the most valuable commodities in the crypto world: a unique digital image of a spiky-haired ape dressed in a spacesuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: New York Officials Fear Supreme Court Ruling Will Mean More Gun Crime
description: The Supreme Court is expected to rule on — and possibly overturn — a century-old law that allows local officials great discretion over who can carry a handgun.
content: Every weekday morning in a nondescript office building in downtown Manhattan, representatives from dozens of law enforcement agencies meet to discuss gun arrests and shootings in New York City from the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: An 1883 Victorian in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom house in Encinitas and a desert compound in Pioneertown.
content: This house was first built in downtown Los Angeles on Bunker Hill, a fashionable area at the time. It has since been moved twice — first in the early 1900s, to an area just west of the city center, and again in 1989. By the middle of the 20th century, most of Bunker Hill had been razed, which makes the survival of this home especially remarkable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: The Parental Burnout Test
description: At what point does the exhaustion working parents feel become something more significant? Take this quiz to find out.
content: At what point does the exhaustion working parents feel become something more significant? Take this quiz to find out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: ‘Crying in H Mart’ Made Michelle Zauner a Literary Star. What's Next?
description: “My creative life has been so raw and personal that I would like to do something more analytical.”
content: “My creative life has been so raw and personal that I would like to do something more analytical.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: An 1883 Victorian in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom house in Encinitas and a desert compound in Pioneertown.
content: An 1883 Victorian in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom house in Encinitas and a desert compound in Pioneertown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Dozens Believed to Be Killed in Nigerian Church Attack, Officials Say
description: At least four gunmen stormed St. Francis Catholic Church in Owo, Nigeria, firing on worshipers celebrating mass and leaving dozens dead, according to local officials.
content: At least four gunmen stormed St. Francis Catholic Church in Owo, Nigeria, firing on worshipers celebrating mass and leaving dozens dead, according to local officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Boris Johnson Survives No-Confidence Vote
description: The vote came amid claims that Mr. Johnson misled Parliament about parties at Downing Street that broke lockdown rules at the height of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The vote came amid claims that Mr. Johnson misled Parliament about parties at Downing Street that broke lockdown rules at the height of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Listen to ‘First Person’
description: To listen to this free New York Times Opinion podcast, follow these instructions.
content: Every opinion starts with a story. A narrative show hosted by Lulu Garcia-Navarro (@lourdesgnavarro). New episodes every Thursday. You can listen to the trailer here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Sheryl Sandberg’s Advice for Working Women
description: Readers discuss what the departing Meta executive’s “lean in” philosophy meant to them. Also: Abortion; sources of morality; the popularity of “Top Gun.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: A no-recipe meal of steak and fiery fruit salsa, Ali Slagle’s green curry glazed tofu, and more recipes.
content: Good morning. A friend stopped by the other night with skirt steak, which struck me as a bit like a friend stopping by with a huge tin of caviar. The price of skirt steak keeps ballooning, and inflation isn’t doing us any favors. I hadn’t cooked with it in months. It felt like a rare and lavish treat.
source.name: The New York Times
